components/esm/loadgmst.hpp

00001 #ifndef _ESM_GMST_H
00002 #define _ESM_GMST_H
00003 
00004 #include "esm_reader.hpp"
00005 #include "defs.hpp"
00006 
00007 namespace ESM {
00008 
00009 /*
00010  *  Game setting, with automatic cleaning of "dirty" entries.
00011  *
00012  */
00013 
00014 struct GameSetting
00015 {
00016   std::string id;
00017 
00018   // One of these is used depending on the variable type
00019   std::string str;
00020   int i;
00021   float f;
00022   VarType type;
00023 
00024   // Set to true if this is a 'dirty' entry which should be ignored
00025   bool dirty;
00026 
00027   /*
00028     These functions check if this game setting is one of the "dirty"
00029     GMST records found in many mods. These are due to a serious bug in
00030     the official TES3 editor. It only occurs in the newer editor
00031     versions that came with Tribunal and Bloodmoon, and only if a
00032     modder tries to make a mod without loading the corresponding
00033     expansion master file. For example, if you have Tribunal installed
00034     and try to make a mod without loading Tribunal.esm, the editor
00035     will insert these GMST records as a replacement for the entries it
00036     cannot find in the ESMs.
00037 
00038     The values of these "dirty" records differ in general from their
00039     values as defined in Tribunal.esm and Bloodmoon.esm, and are
00040     always set to the same "default" values. Most of these values are
00041     nonsensical, ie. changing the "Seller Max" string to "Max Sale",
00042     or change the stats of werewolves to useless values like 1. Some
00043     of them break certain spell effects.
00044   
00045     It is most likely that these values are just leftover values from
00046     an early stage of development that are inserted as default values
00047     by the editor code. They are supposed to be overridden when the
00048     correct esm file is loaded. When it isn't loaded however, you get
00049     stuck with the initial value, and this gets written to every mod
00050     by the editor, for some reason.
00051 
00052     Bethesda themselves have fallen for this bug. If you install both
00053     Tribunal and Bloodmoon, the updated Tribunal.esm will contain the
00054     dirty GMST settings from Bloodmoon, and Bloodmoon.esm will contain
00055     some of the dirty settings from Tribunal. In other words, this bug
00056     affects the game EVEN IF YOU DO NOT USE ANY MODS!
00057 
00058     The guys at Bethesda are well aware of this bug (and many others),
00059     as the mod community and fan base complained about them for a long
00060     time. But unfortunately it was never fixed.
00061 
00062     There are several tools available to help modders remove these
00063     records from their files, but not all modders use them, and they
00064     really shouldn't have to. In this file we choose instead to reject
00065     all the corrupt values at load time.
00066 
00067     These functions checks if the current game setting is one of the
00068     "dirty" ones as described above. TODO: I have not checked this
00069     against other sources yet, do that later. Currently recognizes 22
00070     values for tribunal and 50 for bloodmoon. Legitimate GMSTs in mods
00071     (setting values other than the default "dirty" ones) are not
00072     affected and will work correctly.
00073   */
00074 
00075   // Some handy macros
00076 #define cI(s,x) { if(id == (s)) return (i == (x)); }
00077 #define cF(s,x) { if(id == (s)) return (f == (x)); }
00078 #define cS(s,x) { if(id == (s)) return (str == (x)); }
00079 
00080   /*
00081     Checks for dirty tribunal values. These will be ignored if found
00082     in any file except when they are found in "Tribunal.esm".
00083   */
00084   bool isDirtyTribunal()
00085   {
00086     /*
00087       Here, id contains the game setting name, and we check the
00088       setting for certain values. If it matches, this is a "dirty"
00089       entry. The correct entry (as defined in Tribunal and Bloodmoon
00090       esms) are given in the comments. Many of the values are correct,
00091       and are marked as 'same'. We still ignore them though, as they
00092       are still in the wrong file and might override custom values
00093       from other mods.
00094     */
00095 
00096     // Strings
00097     cS("sProfitValue", "Profit Value");         // 'Profit:'
00098     cS("sEditNote", "Edit Note");               // same
00099     cS("sDeleteNote", "Delete Note?");          // same
00100     cS("sMaxSale", "Max Sale");                 // 'Seller Max'
00101     cS("sMagicFabricantID", "Fabricant");       // 'Fabricant_summon'
00102     cS("sTeleportDisabled",
00103        "Teleportation magic does not work here.");// same
00104     cS("sLevitateDisabled",
00105        "Levitation magic does not work here."); // same
00106     cS("sCompanionShare", "Companion Share");   // 'Share'
00107     cS("sCompanionWarningButtonOne",
00108        "Let the mercenary quit.");              // same
00109     cS("sCompanionWarningButtonTwo",
00110        "Return to Companion Share display.");   // same
00111     cS("sCompanionWarningMessage",
00112        "Your mercenary is poorer now than when he contracted with you.  Your mercenary will quit if you do not give him gold or goods to bring his Profit Value to a positive value.");
00113         // 'Your mercenary is poorer now than when he contracted with
00114         // you.  Your mercenary will quit if you do not give him gold
00115         // or goods to bring his Profit to a positive value.'
00116         // [The difference here is "Profit Value" -> "Profit"]
00117 
00118         // Strings that matches the id
00119     cS("sEffectSummonFabricant", id);// 'Summon Fabricant'
00120     return false;
00121   }
00122 
00123   // Bloodmoon variant
00124   bool isDirtyBloodmoon()
00125   {
00126     // Strings
00127     cS("sWerewolfPopup", "Werewolf");           // same
00128     cS("sWerewolfRestMessage",
00129        "You cannot rest in werewolf form.");    // same
00130     cS("sWerewolfRefusal",
00131        "You cannot do this as a werewolf.");    // same
00132     cS("sWerewolfAlarmMessage",
00133        "You have been detected changing from a werewolf state.");
00134     // 'You have been detected as a known werewolf.'
00135 
00136     // Strings that matches the id
00137     cS("sMagicCreature01ID", id);               // 'BM_wolf_grey_summon'
00138     cS("sMagicCreature02ID", id);               // 'BM_bear_black_summon'
00139     cS("sMagicCreature03ID", id);               // 'BM_wolf_bone_summon'
00140     cS("sMagicCreature04ID", id);               // same
00141     cS("sMagicCreature05ID", id);               // same
00142     cS("sEffectSummonCreature01", id);          // 'Calf Wolf'
00143     cS("sEffectSummonCreature02", id);          // 'Calf Bear'
00144     cS("sEffectSummonCreature03", id);          // 'Summon Bonewolf'
00145     cS("sEffectSummonCreature04", id);          // same
00146     cS("sEffectSummonCreature05", id);          // same
00147 
00148         // Integers
00149     cI("iWereWolfBounty", 10000);               // 1000
00150     cI("iWereWolfFightMod", 100);               // same
00151     cI("iWereWolfFleeMod", 100);                // same
00152     cI("iWereWolfLevelToAttack", 20);           // same
00153 
00154         // Floats
00155     cF("fFleeDistance", 3000);                  // same
00156     cF("fCombatDistanceWerewolfMod", 0.3);      // same
00157     cF("fWereWolfFatigue", 400);                // same
00158     cF("fWereWolfEnchant", 1);                  // 0
00159     cF("fWereWolfArmorer", 1);                  // 0
00160     cF("fWereWolfBlock", 1);                    // 0
00161     cF("fWereWolfSneak", 1);                    // 95
00162     cF("fWereWolfDestruction", 1);              // 0
00163     cF("fWereWolfEndurance", 150);              // same
00164     cF("fWereWolfConjuration", 1);              // 0
00165     cF("fWereWolfRestoration", 1);              // 0
00166     cF("fWereWolfAthletics", 150);              // 50
00167     cF("fWereWolfLuck", 1);                     // 25
00168     cF("fWereWolfSilverWeaponDamageMult", 1.5); // 2
00169     cF("fWereWolfMediumArmor", 1);              // 0
00170     cF("fWereWolfShortBlade", 1);               // 0
00171     cF("fWereWolfAcrobatics", 150);             // 80
00172     cF("fWereWolfSpeechcraft", 1);              // 0
00173     cF("fWereWolfAlteration", 1);               // 0
00174     cF("fWereWolfIllusion", 1);                 // 0
00175     cF("fWereWolfLongBlade", 1);                // 0
00176     cF("fWereWolfMarksman", 1);                 // 0
00177     cF("fWereWolfHandtoHand", 100);             // same
00178     cF("fWereWolfIntellegence", 1);             // 0
00179     cF("fWereWolfAlchemy", 1);                  // 0
00180     cF("fWereWolfUnarmored", 100);              // same
00181     cF("fWereWolfAxe", 1);                      // 0
00182     cF("fWereWolfRunMult", 1.5);                // 1.3
00183     cF("fWereWolfMagicka", 100);                // same
00184     cF("fWereWolfAgility", 150);                // same
00185     cF("fWereWolfBluntWeapon", 1);              // 0
00186     cF("fWereWolfSecurity", 1);                 // 0
00187     cF("fWereWolfPersonality", 1);              // 0
00188     cF("fWereWolfMerchantile", 1);              // 0
00189     cF("fWereWolfHeavyArmor", 1);               // 0
00190     cF("fWereWolfSpear", 1);                    // 0
00191     cF("fWereWolfStrength", 150);               // same
00192     cF("fWereWolfHealth", 2);                   // same
00193     cF("fWereWolfMysticism", 1);                // 0
00194     cF("fWereWolfLightArmor", 1);               // 0
00195     cF("fWereWolfWillPower", 1);                // 0
00196     cF("fWereWolfSpeed", 150);                  // 90
00197     return false;
00198   }
00199 
00200 #undef cI
00201 #undef cF
00202 #undef cS
00203 
00204   void load(ESMReader &esm)
00205   {
00206     assert(id != "");
00207 
00208     dirty = false;
00209 
00210     // We are apparently allowed to be empty
00211     if(!esm.hasMoreSubs())
00212       {
00213         type = VT_None;
00214         return;
00215       }
00216 
00217     // Load some data
00218     esm.getSubName();
00219     NAME n = esm.retSubName();
00220     if(n == "STRV")
00221       {
00222         str = esm.getHString();
00223         type = VT_String;
00224       }
00225     else if(n == "INTV")
00226       {
00227         esm.getHT(i);
00228         type = VT_Int;
00229       }
00230     else if(n == "FLTV")
00231       {
00232         esm.getHT(f);
00233         type = VT_Float;
00234       }
00235     else
00236       esm.fail("Unwanted subrecord type");
00237 
00238     int spf = esm.getSpecial();
00239 
00240     // Check if this is one of the dirty values mentioned above. If it
00241     // is, we set the dirty flag. This will ONLY work if you've set
00242     // the 'id' string correctly before calling load().
00243 
00244     if( ( spf != SF_Tribunal && isDirtyTribunal() ) ||
00245         ( spf != SF_Bloodmoon && isDirtyBloodmoon() ) )
00246       dirty = true;
00247   }
00248 };
00249 }
00250 #endif
